Every author has a target audience when they write a book, and they write about what they think is appropriate for that particular audience. Unfortunately, sometimes other people who don't intend to read the book read it even though @ MONTH1 isn't something they're supposed to read. When an author writes a children's book, it is intended for a child to read, not an adult. Additionally, when an author writes a romance novel, it is for people who can understand what the author is talking about and can act maturely while reading it. Although some @ MONTH1 novels are not suitable for some people, censorship in libraries is not a way to solve this problem, and that is a big mistake. As human beings, we have certain freedoms, and one of those freedoms is freedom of the press. Authors should be able to write about anything they choose to write. If they choose to write on topics that are not suitable for all age groups, they still have the right to have their books in libraries. While not everyone is supposed to read them, some people are. If you take away those books because you're afraid a child might have one, then you take away what some people like to read. Due to the fact that different books are intended for different age groups, libraries have different sections filled with a variety of authors. They have a kids' section designed primarily for kids, an adult section with books that only adults are supposed to read, and a teen section for everyone in between. By having sections within them, libraries try to keep people reading what they were supposed to read without censoring or removing people's favorite books. Having sections in libraries is a happy medium between letting anyone read any book they want, no matter how inappropriate @ MONTH1, and cutting some books all together. If a person is an adult, they should be allowed to go to the library and get whatever kind of book, magazine, music, or movie they want. If a child's parent is okay with checking or watching certain things, it shouldn't matter to someone else if they think the content is offensive. Instead of censoring movies, books, magazines, or library music, there should be a certain age at which someone can walk in without a parent and check out what they want. If a person is under that age, their parents should be present when they leave so they can approve what their child is checking out. Censorship in libraries is ultimately unnecessary and should not even be considered. Whether or not some people find certain materials offensive, there are other ways to get these materials, so there is no need to censor anything in libraries.

The highest rated can be placed in an area that is not seen by the public every day and that is kept secret, thus protecting uninfluenced minds and people who want this material can still do whatever they want. Have you ever found or seen any books, music, movies, or magazines in a library that shock you? If so, would you have wanted to remove it from the shelf so that none of your children or anyone else who might have found it offensive could see it ? Well, I went to the library and saw some gifting things to me, and I also heard my family talking about it. So I am going to talk about what I have heard that my family has seen or found offensive books, music, movies and magazines. Also, I'll explain how I felt and what I wanted to do when I saw these things in a library that I was offering. The last thing I'm going to talk about is how I feel about censorship in libraries. First, I heard my sisters, mom, and mother-in-law tell me how they found books, music, movies, and magazines in a library that shocked them. Now I don't know exactly what they found offensive in books, magazines etc, but I do know what they thought about it and what they wanted to do. So one day my sisters, mom, and stepmom were talking about some books that she found shocking. They never said what the books were, but kept talking about how they felt and what they wished they had done. Now she told me and my family that she was very offended by their name and what they were doing. She also said that she would have really liked to remove books, music, movies, etc. shelves, so that others who may have found them offensive do not see them. But, they all also agreed that they really had no right to take them off the shelves. The reason they don't have this right is that there are a lot of people out there that they don't know if they find it offensive or not. People who don't find it offensive may want to read them. So, they've just agreed to look beyond them and ignore what's there if it offends them to people who don't find them offensive. Now from my perspective to find or see books, music, movies, magazines, etc. in a library that are or were offensive to me. There have been a few times when I walked into a library where I found a few books that were offensive to me. I really didn't like the subject and the name of the books, and I really would have liked to take them off the shelves and throw them away so that no one else who might have found them offensive would find or see them. What if there were other people who actually wanted to read these books? This is what I thought about when I was tempted to delete them. So I decided not to remove the books from the shelves, so that people who didn't find them offensive could read them, if they wanted to. I respected that there are other people who would like to read these books but at the same time I knew there were people who might find them offensive but I just thought they would just ignore the fact that they are there. So, let's move on to the last thing I'm going to talk about. Do I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from library shelves if they are found to be offensive ? Also my take on censorship in libraries. Well I think they should be removed so that they don't offend anyone who walks into this library. But, if people had the right to take books or anything offensive to them, then there would literally be no books left in the libraries. So there would be no point in having libraries or anyone writing books. So again, I don't think anyone should have the right to just remove books that are offensive to them. I believe if they find a book that is offensive to them then they should just ignore that it is there and respect the fact that there are a lot of people out there who would or would like to read these books. So I don't think there should be any censorship in libraries at all. It is no one's fault that people find books, music, movies, magazines, etc. offensive to them. So no, there should absolutely be no censorship in a library. So there I just explained my take on censorship in libraries and whether I believe people should have the right to take books off a shelf just because they found it offensive. As I said before, there should be no censorship in libraries. But yes, I understand that people find things offensive, but they should just ignore that they are there and respect that there are people out there who want or would like to read these books. Again, do you think people should be allowed to take a book off the shelf just because they find it offensive, and what do you think about censorship in libraries ?

Censorship. It's a word everyone has heard, but do people really know what it means or how it affects them? In the past, books have been censored by rulers and managers who thought the material was harmful. How could they say they knew what was best for their people? What gave them the right to decide what their people could and couldn't read? In today's society, we still face censorship issues. There are still people who believe that libraries should censor their books. Censorship is bad. Books, magazines, movies, music, etc. should not be taken off the shelves just because some people find them offensive. Everyone has different tastes, not only in food, but also in every other aspect of their life. No one has the right to say that one genre is better than another. Censorship is bad because it limits what people can read, watch and listen to. Censorship should not be allowed because it limits what people can read. Some people like mysteries, while others like to read romantic books. If we allow people to censor what we read, then how can we say that this is a book that everyone loves? If libraries censored all books that could offend someone else, then there would be no more books to read. For example, some religious books may offend people of other faiths, but that doesn't mean we should take them off the shelves. If we did this, we would have to remove all religious books so that no one would be offended. Then no one could find any books on his religion, and no one would benefit from them. Likewise, censorship limits what people can watch. If we took out every movie that had even a tiny bit that offended someone else, there wouldn't be any more movies in the world. Every movie will have something that someone will love and someone will hate. If we just focus on the person who hates it and we get rid of movies based on people who hate them, then people who love movies will suffer. People who love horror movies probably hate comedies. That doesn't mean we have to get rid of comedies just because there are people out there who hate them. It only means that people who don't like this type of movie don't have to watch them. Likewise, censorship prevents people from enjoying the kind of music they like. We can't censor music because everyone has different types and genres that they like. If we take out one genre of music, then we have to take out all genres of music. It's not fair to say that we can censor a genre of music because some people don't like it or find it offensive when there are people who really like to listen to that kind of music. It would be unfair to these people, and if we are unfair to them, we have to be unfair to everyone. People would be even more offended than before in this case. There will always be unhappy people in the world. We shouldn't censor books, movies, and music in libraries and other places just to try to make people happy. Censorship in libraries limits what people can enjoy. It drives people who would love censored articles crazy. We shouldn't come to this. We should allow people to choose what they like. If a person wants to read something, he should be allowed. If they want to watch a certain movie or listen to a certain song, why not let them do it? The small margin of people who dislike what those people like may simply avoid reading it, watching it, or listening to it. You can't take something away from people who love it just because someone is unhappy.
